instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-4924: What is 820-4924? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.SMC_RESET_L: What is SMC_RESET_L? SMC_RESET_L puts the SMC into reset mode when it is low, _L means the signal is present when voltage is low. The SMC being in reset mode keeps it from running..
definitions.PP5V_S0: What is PP5V_S0? PP5V_S0 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S0 working state..
definitions.SMC_LID: What is SMC_LID? SMC_LID tells the machine the system is open when it is 3.3v to 3.4v, and closed when it is low such as 0v-0.6v. When this signal is low, the machine may go to sleep or have no backlight. .
definitions.PP3V3_S0: What is PP3V3_S0? The "PP3V3_S0" rail in a MacBook logic board is a power rail that supplies 3.3 volts to the system when it is fully awake (S0 state). .
definitions.U1950: What is U1950? This chip often becomes corroded on pin 8 on the PP3V42_G3H pin causing PM_SLP_S4_L to go missing.
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Powers Up But No Chime or Display
threads.message:
Ok this one has gotten me completely stumped. Initially the macbook came in with water damage and the keyboard wasnt working. Opened it up and found Pin 4 of J4813 was burned away also some corrosion around <TRANSISTOR>Q7520</TRANSISTOR>. Replaced J4813 and cleaned up the area around <TRANSISTOR>Q7520</TRANSISTOR> - turned on got to the boot selection screen tested the keyboard to find some keys are still not functional. Tried it once more with a new keyboard and looks like working fully with the new keyboard. Replaced the keyboard in the case plug everything back in - turns on but no display or chime but CPU is getting warm, do some more troubleshooting find out it turns on fine and goes to the flashing folder screen without the touchpad connected. Quick inspection of the touchpad later see some corrosion on there and decide best option is to replace the touchpad and cable. Fitted the new touchpad testing once more before plugging it in that the machine still gives the flashing folder screen which it did, plug the new touchpad in and same problem as before no display, no chime. Think i'll just unplug the touchpad and hopefully get back to where I was before but no even with no other parts connected other than Screen and Magsafe port I get no display or chime. Tried external display also no display, also USB mouse isnt lighting up either. Tried PRAM reset with external keyboard but nothing. 

Checked some voltages:
I have CPU VCore and cpu is warming up
<SIGNAL>SMC_LID</SIGNAL> is High
<SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> is High
PPBUS is 12V
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL> is 5V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL> is 3.3V


What I have done to try to rectify the issue so far:
Removed <TRANSISTOR>Q7520</TRANSISTOR> and replaced - same
Inspected board for other signs of corrosion finding a tiny amount around <CAPACITOR>C7372</CAPACITOR> which I have removed, also a tiny amount around pins 1 and 2 of <CHIP>U7700</CHIP> which i have cleaned up 
Removed the glue around the SMC and reflowed it with flux 

As it stands now i've reached a point where I could use some pointers in the right direction as to what to check/try next to get this board functioning properly again. Thanks in advance for any help you can provide!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Powers Up But No Chime or Display
threads.message: Check for corrosion around <CHIP>U1900</CHIP>, check if there is some activity on USB port.....

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Powers Up But No Chime or Display
threads.message: Checked for corrosion around <CHIP>U1900</CHIP> - none visible. Replaced <CHIP>U1900</CHIP> anyway from a donor board but same - still got cpu vcore but no chime/display. As for activity on USB - nothing at all with USB mouse or keyboard - if I plug a USB flash drive with a light on it though it does light up for a few seconds.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Powers Up But No Chime or Display
threads.message: <CHIP>U1950</CHIP> is also a common corrosion suspect. But it could be anything really, crap under SMC is also suspect.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Powers Up But No Chime or Display
threads.message: For sure listen to Duke on this because I literally just had one like this where it worked once and then had no image, chime etc despite VCore being present. Replaced <CHIP>U1950</CHIP> and it worked, so it can definitely screw things up even if it looks ok.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Powers Up But No Chime or Display
threads.message: Checked <CHIP>U1950</CHIP> - looked clean but replaced anyway - unfortunately it hasnt made any difference. SMC has been reflowed also with no effect.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Powers Up But No Chime or Display
threads.message:
At this point it could be anything ranging from corrosion under a chip to a small component knocked off while doing the work. 

Seeing that there was corrosion on <CAPACITOR>C7372</CAPACITOR> is it possible there is more corrosion in the <CHIP>U7200</CHIP> area?
Check carefully for any damaged or knocked off components.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Powers Up But No Chime or Display
threads.message: Given <CHIP>U7200</CHIP> another look - can't see any other signs of corrosion around it. One interesting observation I have made is that the <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> rail appears to have quite a low resistance to ground 45ohms or so. I'm not sure if that is normal on this 2015 board as I do not have another one to compare it to.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Powers Up But No Chime or Display
threads.message: That is way to low. Is that with everything disconnected from the board? 45 Ohm is too high for heating anything up so it will be a process of elimination.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Powers Up But No Chime or Display
threads.message:
Yes that was with everything disconnected from the board. Decided to take a risk and pull the SMC off the board - looked fairly clean underneath if i'm being honest but testing <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> for shorts afterwards was showing 2.2k ohms and not the 45ohms it was before. It's pointing me to think that either there was crap under the SMC which caused the problem and pulling it off has cleaned it or the SMC itself is bad.

Update: Reballed and replaced SMC - partial short on <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> is back this time at 48ohms so that leads me to conclude this SMC is the issue.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Powers Up But No Chime or Display
threads.message: Yeah bad SMC then. Get an identical donor board and swap SMC.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Powers Up But No Chime or Display
threads.message: You could confirm for short directly on smc while removed by testing on gnd and <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> balls. So you don't need to reball and solder it back to finally confirm the short.
